pr_title: Map count metric in phonehome with some code refactor

timeline.message: Map Count metric alongwith code refactor

timeline.author: erosb

timeline.body: It would be better to create a new collection instead of mutating the collection returned by `#getDistributedObjects()`. Can you implement it with the stream API?

erosb

timeline.body:
I suggest encoding the above 4 assertions in a single call: `assertEquals(ImmutableMap.of("1", "hazelcast", "2", "phonehome"), map);`.

In general it is a good practice to check the expected output in one assertion, instead of checking its pieces separately.

Also, in these `assertEquals()` calls the expected and the actual values are mixed up. First should come the expected, then second the actual. Of course it works this way too, but if the assertion fails, then the output becomes confusing if the expected and actual are swapped, so it is useful to always put them in the correct order.

timeline.author: erosb

timeline.body:
Given that there will be several other metrics being collected, it would be better not to wrap all the metric collector calls into separate private methods of `PhoneHome`.

We can assume that there will be several further metric collector classes. Instead of using them in separate methods, it would be more concise if
 * there would be a `MetricCollector` interface
 * the `PhoneHome` would have a `List<MetricCollector> collectors` field, with a hardcoded list as its value
 * the PhoneHome would iterate on the `collectors` list, use them to compute the metric values, and put the values into the `PhoneHomeParameterCreator` instance.

For now we can also assume that
 * a single MetricCollector implementation will compute multiple metrics
 * the MetricCollector implementations can do its job given a `Node`, no other data source is necessary for it.

Given these guidelines, can you design the `MetricCollector` interface?

As the following step, can you further simplify the `PhoneHome` by extracting the cluster info and build info related metrics into `MetricCollector` implementations?
timeline.bodyText:
Given that there will be several other metrics being collected, it would be better not to wrap all the metric collector calls into separate private methods of PhoneHome.
We can assume that there will be several further metric collector classes. Instead of using them in separate methods, it would be more concise if

there would be a MetricCollector interface
the PhoneHome would have a List<MetricCollector> collectors field, with a hardcoded list as its value
the PhoneHome would iterate on the collectors list, use them to compute the metric values, and put the values into the PhoneHomeParameterCreator instance.

For now we can also assume that

a single MetricCollector implementation will compute multiple metrics
the MetricCollector implementations can do its job given a Node, no other data source is necessary for it.

Given these guidelines, can you design the MetricCollector interface?
As the following step, can you further simplify the PhoneHome by extracting the cluster info and build info related metrics into MetricCollector implementations?
timeline.bodyHTML:
Given that there will be several other metrics being collected, it would be better not to wrap all the metric collector calls into separate private methods of PhoneHome.

We can assume that there will be several further metric collector classes. Instead of using them in separate methods, it would be more concise if

  • there would be a MetricCollector interface
  • the PhoneHome would have a List<MetricCollector> collectors field, with a hardcoded list as its value
  • the PhoneHome would iterate on the collectors list, use them to compute the metric values, and put the values into the PhoneHomeParameterCreator instance.

For now we can also assume that

  • a single MetricCollector implementation will compute multiple metrics
  • the MetricCollector implementations can do its job given a Node, no other data source is necessary for it.

Given these guidelines, can you design the MetricCollector interface?

As the following step, can you further simplify the PhoneHome by extracting the cluster info and build info related metrics into MetricCollector implementations?
timeline.author: erosb

timeline.body: nit: it would be cleaner to create this list as a field. You can use `java.util.Arrays.asList(...)` to create the array, instead of adding the values to an ArrayList.

timeline.author: erosb

timeline.body: It would be a nice improvement to check if the `parameters` map already contains the new key to be added, and throw an `IllegalArgumentException` in that case. It would help to ensure that the map keys returned by the collectors are unique, to avoid accidentally using the a key for multiple purposes. Please also add a unittest to PhoneHomeParameterCreator covering this check.
timeline.bodyText: It would be a nice improvement to check if the parameters map already contains the new key to be added, and throw an IllegalArgumentException in that case. It would help to ensure that the map keys returned by the collectors are unique, to avoid accidentally using the a key for multiple purposes. Please also add a unittest to PhoneHomeParameterCreator covering this check.
timeline.bodyHTML: It would be a nice improvement to check if the parameters map already contains the new key to be added, and throw an IllegalArgumentException in that case. It would help to ensure that the map keys returned by the collectors are unique, to avoid accidentally using the a key for multiple purposes. Please also add a unittest to PhoneHomeParameterCreator covering this check.

timeline.body: This is a duplicate of the same method in `BuildInfoCollector`. Please extract it into a common place. I suggest extracting it as a static method of the `MetricCollector` interface. Since it is used by the implementations of the interface, it is a good-enough approach.

timeline.body: nit: please static-import `Collectors.toList()`. That reads better, since `collect(toList())` is almost the same as "collect into a list" in English.

timeline.body: Since we have the `assertEquals(ImmutableMap.of("1", "hazelcast", "2", "phonehome"), map);` check now, you can remove the `assertNotNull(map);` and the `assertNull(map.get("3"));` assertions, since these are unnecessary. The `assertEquals()` call covers these conditions.

timeline.body: There is no need to keep this method `public` anymore, since it isn't used from the outside. You can even remove it and just do `mapInfo.put("mpct", String.valueOf(maps.size()));` in `computeMetrics()`.

timeline.author: erosb

timeline.body:
`Arrays.asList()` accepts variable-length argument list, so you can write `List<MetricsCollector> metricsCollectorList = Arrays.asList(new BuildInfoCollector(), new ClusterInfoCollector(), ...);` and drop the `metricsCollectorArray` variable.

Also please let's make it a field instead of a local variable.
timeline.bodyText:
Arrays.asList() accepts variable-length argument list, so you can write List<MetricsCollector> metricsCollectorList = Arrays.asList(new BuildInfoCollector(), new ClusterInfoCollector(), ...); and drop the metricsCollectorArray variable.
Also please let's make it a field instead of a local variable.
timeline.bodyHTML:
Arrays.asList() accepts variable-length argument list, so you can write List<MetricsCollector> metricsCollectorList = Arrays.asList(new BuildInfoCollector(), new ClusterInfoCollector(), ...); and drop the metricsCollectorArray variable.

Also please let's make it a field instead of a local variable.
timeline.author: erosb
